biography:
An early album was the techstep effort, Metropolis/Mother Earth, released in 1997 on the Metalheadz record label. His other early successes were the tracks "F-Jam" and "Circles" (the latter breaking into the Top 20 in the UK Singles Chart). In 1998 he won a MOBO award for his debut album, Colours. In 2001, he found success in the field of hip hop, primarily with his ground breaking collaborative musical effort, KAOS - The Anti-Acoustic Warfare, working alongside artists such as LL Cool J, Redman and De La Soul. In 2002, Adam created the score for the feature film Ali G Indahouse starring Sacha Baron Cohen for Working Title Films.

He is founder and co-owner of the UK independent record label, Breakbeat Kaos, which released Pendulum's platinum selling album, Hold Your Colour; he is also co-owner of the drum and bass website, Dogs on Acid.

In early 2007, under the guidance of Hollywood talent manager Stacey Castro, Adam entered the world of acting and was immediately cast in his first film role, the British indie crime thriller The Heavy. In December 2007, Adam also co-starred in a British feature film, Cuckoo, a thriller about sound and lies, co-starring Richard E. Grant and Laura Fraser, directed by Richard Bracewell.
name: Adam F

discogs.name: Adam F
discogs.profile:
DJ & producer born in Liverpool, latterly from Kings Langley, Hertfordshire. Son of [a=Alvin Stardust] & nephew of Rory Storm ([a=Rory Storm & The Hurricanes]). Married to [a=Kirsty Hawkshaw].

Owned the [l=F-Jams] label & [l=Bible Studios]. He is also one of the co-owners of the Dogs On Acid internet D'n'B forum. As a teen he also played keyboards on a U.S. tour for [a=The Moody Blues].

theaudiodb.biography_en:
An early album was the techstep effort, Metropolis/Mother Earth, released in 1997 on the Metalheadz record label. His other early successes were the tracks "F-Jam" and "Circles" (the latter breaking into the Top 20 in the UK Singles Chart). In 1998 he won a MOBO award for his debut album, Colours. In 2001, he found success in the field of hip hop, primarily with his ground breaking collaborative musical effort, KAOS - The Anti-Acoustic Warfare, working alongside artists such as LL Cool J, Redman and De La Soul. In 2002, Adam created the score for the feature film Ali G Indahouse starring Sacha Baron Cohen for Working Title Films.

He is founder and co-owner of the UK independent record label, Breakbeat Kaos, which released Pendulum's platinum selling album, Hold Your Colour; he is also co-owner of the drum and bass website, Dogs on Acid.

In early 2007, under the guidance of Hollywood talent manager Stacey Castro, Adam entered the world of acting and was immediately cast in his first film role, the British indie crime thriller The Heavy. In December 2007, Adam also co-starred in a British feature film, Cuckoo, a thriller about sound and lies, co-starring Richard E. Grant and Laura Fraser, directed by Richard Bracewell.
theaudiodb.name: Adam F

lastfm.bio_content: DJ Adam F (Born in Liverpool, England) is a jungle/drum and bass producer and DJ. His father pop singer Bernard William Jewry, known as Alvin Stardust. Adam F's breakthrough hit was the techstep single Metropolis/Mother Earth, released in 1997 on the Metalheadz record label. He signed to the EMI label in the UK and in 1998 won a MOBO award for his debut album Colours, containing the UK Top 20 hits Music in my Mind, Circles and Brand New Funk. He has also found success in the field of hip hop, primarily with his collaborative musical effort KAOS - The Anti-Accoustic Warfare. He has worked with rapper LL Cool J and Missy Elliott. He produced tracks on L.L Cool J's first No:1 USA Billboard album. He is also founder and co-owner of the UK independent record label Breakbeat Kaos who signed Pendulum and released the platinum selling album Hold Your Colour, as well as singles and albums from Chase & Status and The Brookes Brothers. Adam has composer credits in several films, including "Ali G Indahouse". Adam also has 8 gold discs and 2 platinum awards to date. In 2010, Adam is working with Redman and Nick Halkes (aka Horx), the man who launched both XL Recordings and Positiva. It was Nick who originally signed Adam to Positiva. He is married to Kirsty Hawkshaw, a member of group Opus III. Read more on Last.fm. User-contributed text is available under the Creative Commons By-SA License; additional terms may apply.
lastfm.bio_summary: DJ Adam F (Born in Liverpool, England) is a jungle/drum and bass producer and DJ. His father pop singer Bernard William Jewry, known as Alvin Stardust. Adam F's breakthrough hit was the techstep single Metropolis/Mother Earth, released in 1997 on the Metalheadz record label. He signed to the EMI label in the UK and in 1998 won a MOBO award for his debut album Colours, containing the UK Top 20 hits Music in my Mind, Circles and Brand New Funk. Read more on Last.fm

An early album was the techstep effort, Metropolis/Mother Earth, released in 1997 on the Metalheadz record label. His other early successes were the tracks "F-Jam" and "Circles" (the latter breaking into the Top 20 in the UK Singles Chart). In 1998 he won a MOBO award for his debut album, Colours. In 2001, he found success in the field of hip hop, primarily with his ground breaking collaborative musical effort, KAOS - The Anti-Acoustic Warfare, working alongside artists such as LL Cool J, Redman and De La Soul. In 2002, Adam created the score for the feature film Ali G Indahouse starring Sacha Baron Cohen for Working Title Films.

He is founder and co-owner of the UK independent record label, Breakbeat Kaos, which released Pendulum's platinum selling album, Hold Your Colour; he is also co-owner of the drum and bass website, Dogs on Acid.

In early 2007, under the guidance of Hollywood talent manager Stacey Castro, Adam entered the world of acting and was immediately cast in his first film role, the British indie crime thriller The Heavy. In December 2007, Adam also co-starred in a British feature film, Cuckoo, a thriller about sound and lies, co-starring Richard E. Grant and Laura Fraser, directed by Richard Bracewell.
